snippet: George Zimmerman, charged with murdering Trayvon Martin, is likely to skip a chance to have his case dismissed and take it directly to a jury, his lawyer said.
abstract: George Zimmerman, charged with second-degree murder in killing of Sanford, Fla, teenager Trayvon Martin, is likely to take his case directly to jury, skipping pretrial self-defense hearing under Florida's Stand Your Ground law; hearing would allow a judge to decide whether to grant immunity from prosecution under the law, but Zimmerman's attorney expresses his client's preference to have a jury of peers decide his case.
lead_paragraph: George Zimmerman, charged with murdering Trayvon Martin, is likely to skip a chance to have his case dismissed and take it directly to a jury, his lawyer said.

headline.seo: Trayvon Martin’s Killer Favors Trial Over Immunity Hearing
headline.main: For Floridian, Murder Trial Beats Self-Defense Hearing
headline.print_headline: For Floridian, Murder Trial Beats Self-Defense Hearing
